Introducing IMGKit

I recently discovered JD Pace's PDFKit in the search for better ways to do things. It's a great solution for generating PDF files from html sources. It is basically a wrapper for the open source executable wkhtmltopdf.

The idea behind wkhtmltopdf is simple: use the rendering engine of browser without the gui and you'll have pages that look exactly like they render on the web!

With that background in mind, I set forth to tackle a new requirement for a task I had at hand: turning an HTML page into a JPG. With my PDFKit hammer at my side, I quickly strung together a processing pipeline that used PDFKit to transform my html to a PDF and then RMagick to transmogrify the PDF into JPG. I looked something like this:

    pdf  = PDFKit.new(html, :page_size => 'Letter').to_pdf
    gif  = Magick::Image.from_blob(pdf)

Simple, for sure. But it looked like SHIT. Back to the drawing board. A big problem was all the fine text was illegible. Imagemagick seemed to be doing a bad job of rasterizing the text getting produced in the PDF. I reasoned that perhaps I could find a flag in wkhtmltopdf to rasterize the text. Instead, I found something better. Something much better...

wkhtmltoimage

It turns out wkhtmlto_image does for JPGs what wkthmlto_pdf does for PDFs. Woot! Like any good hacker, I first decided to try to screw around with the PDFKit gem, swapping out the call to wkhtmltopdf with one to wkhtmltoimage.

As that broke, it lead me to try to just call the command on my own, which eventually lead to this little gem of Ruby:

stdin and stdout and stderr, oh my!

    pdf = Kernel.open('|-', "w+")
    exec(*command) if pdf.nil?
    pdf.puts(@source.to_s) if @source.html?
    pdf.close_write
    result = pdf.gets(nil)
    pdf.close_read

It turns out you can open a pipe with Kernel#open that you can read and write to like a file! Moments like this make me really appreciate the power of the 'file' abstraction. If you pass '|' you will have a pipe that you can read and write to with normal file methods, such as #gets, #puts, and my favorite #<<. if you pass the special string '|-' to Kernel#open, not only do you get back a pipe, but the process forks, returning nil to the child and the file-like pipe Object to the parent. That's a pretty elegant way to wrap a process.

This may make it more clear:

in Ruby, files can be pipes...

    pipe = Kernel.open('|-', "w+")
    exec(*command) if pipe.nil?
    pipe.puts(@source.to_s) if @source.html?
    pipe.close_write
    result = pipe.gets(nil)
    pipe.close_read

So I got to quick work writing my own script that just called wkhtmltoimage with this bit of code. However, wkthmltoimage does not support the --quiet flag, which leads to leaky standard error printing out the the console. This is something that is very noticable during unit testing and is just a bad form and practice to not manage right.

The command we are wrapping is 'wkhtmltoimage', which takes two inputs: the source and ouptut destination. It can take a url, file location, or stdin as input if you pass the special parameter '-'. Output can either be a file or standard out if you use the same '-'. In this situation, we're always reading from standard out, which is accomplished via the call to result = pdf.gets(nil)

Standard error, you bastard!

PDFKit is able to pass the --quiet flag to wkhtmltopdf to silence standard error. Unfortunately, wkhtmltoimage has no such flag. Using redirection is one way out and works fine when passing the command as a string to exec, a la "wkhtmltoimage - - 2&/dev/null". However, this fails when using the splat operator on a bunch of built up parameters. It turns out Ruby has another way to call a process that while not as terse as the above, does a great job:

    result = nil
    Open3.popen3(*command) do |stdin,stdout,stderr|
      stdin << (@source.to_s) if @source.html?
      stdin.close
      result = stdout.gets(nil)
      stdout.close
      stderr.close
    end

The call to exec in the Kernel#open method does not provide a way to manage the output of standard error in the child process, so it winds up connected to the parent's standard error. Open3#open3 allows you to explicitly manage standard input, output, and error of the child process command. Since we're not really interested in what it has to say, we just close it when we're done reading the jpg on stdout.

Rolling my own

Eventually I made enough changes to the PDFKit to warrant creating my own library I am calling IMGKit, which I am proud to announce is available via:

gem install imgkit

You can then create JPGs from HTML files with:

    require 'imgkit'
    kit = IMGKit.new(html, :quality => 50)
    kit.stylesheets << '/path/to/css/file'
    
    # Get the image BLOB
    img = kit.to_img
    
    # Save the JPG to a file
    file = kit.to_file('/path/to/save/file.jpg')

Code is available on github.

Oh, and this is my first gem!
